ConceptDef.label: Camera dolly
ConceptDef.helpText: Move the camera by clicking and dragging the MOUSE BUTTON 3 (middle button) or with the {Key:MapDolly_Up}-{Key:MapDolly_Left}-{Key:MapDolly_Down}-{Key:MapDolly_Right} keys.

ConceptDef.label: Camera zoom
ConceptDef.helpText: Zoom in and out with the MOUSEWHEEL or the {Key:MapZoom_In} and {Key:MapZoom_Out} keys.

ConceptDef.label: Time controls
ConceptDef.helpText: You can speed up time.\n\nTry controlling time with the {Key:TimeSpeed_Normal}, {Key:TimeSpeed_Fast}, and {Key:TimeSpeed_Superfast} keys, or with the time controls in the bottom right.

ConceptDef.label: Pausing
ConceptDef.helpText:
Hit {Key:TogglePause} to pause or unpause the game.

You can give orders while paused.

Remember this - if things get hectic, just hit {Key:TogglePause}!

ConceptDef.label: Stockpiles
ConceptDef.helpText: Your colonists need somewhere to store items. Designate a STOCKPILE for them to store things.\n\nFind the stockpile in the ZONES section of the ARCHITECT menu in the lower-left.

ConceptDef.label: Forbid and allow
ConceptDef.helpText: Colonists will not interact with items marked FORBIDDEN.\n\nForbidden items have a small red X attached. Select a forbidden item and use the controls at the bottom to ALLOW it.

ConceptDef.label: Growing zones
ConceptDef.helpText: To grow food, place GROWING ZONES using the Architect menu.\n\nThey can only be placed on fertile ground.

ConceptDef.label: Equipping weapons
ConceptDef.helpText: Your colonists arrived with some weapons. Equip them!\n\nSelect each colonist and right-click on the weapon you want them to equip.

ConceptDef.label: Alerts
ConceptDef.helpText: The alerts at the right edge of the screen tell you about issues that need your attention.\n\nKeep an eye on the alerts.

ConceptDef.label: Mining
ConceptDef.helpText: You can designate where to mine by opening the ARCHITECT menu and selecting the ORDERS tab.\n\nSome mineable blocks yield STEEL, GOLD, PLASTEEL, and other useful materials.

ConceptDef.label: Work settings
ConceptDef.helpText:
You can set each colonist's work settings in the WORK tab at the bottom left of the screen.

They will always do the highest priority work that they can find.

If nobody has a certain work type assigned, or if they are busy with higher-priority tasks, it will never get done.

ConceptDef.label: Forbidding doors
ConceptDef.helpText: You can FORBID doors so colonists and tame animals won't go through them.\n\nNote that this isn't a door lock. Doors are always locked, so enemies can't pass freely. Forbidding just directs your colonists not to use the door. Colonists who are going crazy might use the door anyway.

ConceptDef.label: Cover and shooting
ConceptDef.helpText:
The most important thing to do in ranged combat is to use cover.

Cover only works if your colonist is touching it, and it is between your colonist and the enemy.

You can also place colonists behind wall corners. They will lean out to shoot.

Most things can be used as cover, but some things are better than others. Hiding behind a tree is better than nothing, but hiding behind sandbags is better than using a tree.

ConceptDef.label: Forming caravans
ConceptDef.helpText: You can form a caravan to send groups of people traveling across the planet!\n\nIn the WORLD tab, select your home base and click the "form caravan" button.

ConceptDef.label: Animal taming
ConceptDef.helpText:
You can assign colonists to tame a wild animal with the TAME designator.

Colonists will offer the animal food and attempt to tame it.

Beware: Some animals can respond violently to failed taming attempts.

ConceptDef.label: Animal training
ConceptDef.helpText: You can assign a tame animal to be trained in specific skills on its TRAINING tab.\n\nAnimals can't be trained continuously; they need time between training sessions.

ConceptDef.label: Info card
ConceptDef.helpText: The info card shows you detailed statistics about any item, person, or construction.\n\nSelect a person or item and open their info card with the 'i' button on the inspect pane.

ConceptDef.label: Storage tab
ConceptDef.helpText:
You can configure stockpiles and storage buildings by selecting them and opening the STORAGE TAB above the bottom-left inspector pane.

In the storage tab of a stockpile, you can expand categories to allow or deny specific items. Click the triangles to the left of category names.

You can change the PRIORITY of storage. Colonists will fill higher-priority storage first, and move items from lower to higher priority.

ConceptDef.label: Home area
ConceptDef.helpText: The HOME AREA tells your colonists which area to clean and where to extinguish fires.\n\nDefine the HOME AREA with the Zones category under the Architect menu.

ConceptDef.label: Spoilage and freezers
ConceptDef.helpText:
Most foodstuffs will spoil after a relatively short time.

To prevent this, you can build a walk-in freezer.

To build a freezer, construct a closed room, and put one or two coolers into the wall. Set the coolers to a negative target temperature.

Frozen foods won't ever spoil.

ConceptDef.label: Item deterioration
ConceptDef.helpText: Items left outdoors will slowly deteriorate.\n\nIf you want to store items long-term, keep them in a roofed room.

ConceptDef.label: Hostility response modes
ConceptDef.helpText: You can configure how colonists should automatically respond to threats like predatory animals.\n\nChoose from FLEE, ATTACK, and IGNORE modes in the ASSIGN menu.

ConceptDef.label: Allowed areas
ConceptDef.helpText:
Colonists and colony animals can be assigned to ALLOWED AREAS. This forbids them from taking destinations outside their allowed area.

This can be used to, for example, forbid colonists from going outside.

You can create multiple allowed areas and assign them to different colonists and animals.

Create, delete, and assign allowed areas in the RESTRICT tab.

Paint allowed areas onto the map using the EXPAND ALLOWED AREA and CLEAR ALLOWED AREA designators in the Architect tab.

ConceptDef.label: Medical operations
ConceptDef.helpText: To assign a medical operation, like organ harvesting or prosthetics installation, open a colonist's HEALTH tab, then switch to the OPERATIONS sub-tab.

ConceptDef.label: Time assignments
ConceptDef.helpText: You can modify what time of day colonists should do different activities using the RESTRICT tab.

ConceptDef.label: Manual work priorities
ConceptDef.helpText:
One of the most important parts of RimWorld is choosing good work settings for your colonists.

Poor work settings can leave essential work unfinished for a long time while colonists waste time on unimportant tasks.

To give more control over what work colonists do, you can use the Manual Priorities mode in the WORK tab.

In this mode, each colonist has a priority number for each work type. Colonists will do priority 1 work from left to right, then priority 2 work from left to right, and so on.

Intelligent use of these setting is essential for a large, well-automated colony.

ConceptDef.label: Getting more traders
ConceptDef.helpText:
More trader caravans will come to visit you if you're allied with more factions.

If you have no allies, no caravans will ever visit!

You can also pay allies to send trade caravans by calling them on the comms console.

ConceptDef.label: Room stats inspector
ConceptDef.helpText: You can inspect the impressiveness, wealth, and beauty of individual rooms using the ROOM STATS INSPECT toggle in the bottom right.

ConceptDef.label: Outfits
ConceptDef.helpText:
Colonists will automatically try to wear the newest, highest-quality apparel they can.

You don't need to manually assign each piece of apparel to colonists (though you can, if you wish).

To assign colonists restrictions on how to dress, open the ASSIGN tab, use the "Manage outfits" dialog box to design a new outfit, and then assign the outfit to colonists.

ConceptDef.label: Fire preparation
ConceptDef.helpText:
Fires can easily burn down a colony. To defeat them, you must prepare before they happen. 
These design elements can help reduce the damage from fires: 
1. Instead of constructing one super-building, build separate buildings with spaces in between. 
2. Use less flammable materials. Wood is cheap and fast - but very flammable. 
3. Build firebreaks to stop wildfires approaching your base. A strip of concrete floor 3 or 4 cells wide will generally stop an advancing fire.

ConceptDef.label: History tab
ConceptDef.helpText: You can see a record of your colony's fortunes over time in the HISTORY tab at the bottom of the screen.

ConceptDef.label: Clicking messages
ConceptDef.helpText: You can click on the notifications in the top-left of the screen to instantly center the camera on their subject.

ConceptDef.label: Shot accuracy tooltip
ConceptDef.helpText: You can see the exact calculations behind the accuracy of any shot.\n\nTo do so, select the shooter, then rest the mouse over the target. The tooltip will show the chance to hit, and a breakdown of the contribution of various to-hit chance multipliers.

ConceptDef.label: Friendly fire safety
ConceptDef.helpText:
Friendly fire never occurs if the shooter is close to their ally.

For example, you can safely put a sword-wielding colonist directly in front of a gun-wielding one. The shooter will fire over his friend's shoulder.

This is a good way to combine ranged and melee fighters.
